text: you know many economists will tell you
that the recipe for a strong sustainable
economy is actually very simple make
sure you don't put all your eggs in one
basket
in other words diversity is the key
having an economy that's based on lots
of different things for example
manufacturing and agriculture and
farming maybe new technologies
IT and software and for some countries
tourism is a very important source of
income but diversity isn't something the
russian economy is known for russia has
placed all its economic eggs in one
basket it's heavily reliant on one thing
exporting energy selling its oil and gas
most of that has been going to Europe in
fact it's gas sales to Europe that
generates 80% of the revenue of the
Russian energy giant Gazprom but now
there's a problem tension over Ukraine
means friction with Russia's main
customer European governments are really
looking to reduce their dependency on
Russian energy now that won't happen
overnight but it's pushing Russia to
seek alternative markets and new
customers so if President Putin can
clinch an energy deal with Beijing this
week very soon
Russian gas could be heading to China
it's an agreement the two countries have
been talking about for years but they've
been unable to agree on a price if it is
signed that would be good for China it
has an insatiable appetite for energy to
feed its growing economy and it would
allow Russia to turn around to the West
and say you don't want our energy that's
fine we found someone else to buy it the
Russians have been scrambling to
finalize the deal with China because
they know that serious cracks have
emerged in Moscow's relationship with
the West
